>
>Chappell, Simon P wrote:=

>> We're having some "robust" discussions about testing here 
>and one of =
the 
>> big issues concerns correct nomenclature for testing types 
>and le=
vels 
>> and scopes. Does anyone have any book recommendations to help with=
 
>> industry accepted terms and definitions? I have seen 
>references to "=
The 
>> Art of Software Testing" by Glenford Myers that describe it as the =

>> seminal work on the matter. Is that book worth getting? Is there a 
>> =
website anywhere that has "standard" definitions that my 
>co-workers and 
=
>> I can use for enlightenment on this matter?
>> 
>> All wisdom on this ma=
tter will be greatly appreciated.
>
>Here's wisdom that nevertheless doesn'=
t help you: it doesn't matter.

JB, that's good wisdom, but you're right, i=
t doesn't answer my question.

>If they're getting hung up on what words me=
an in some ethereal objective 
>sense, rather than simply finding a workabl=
e vocabulary to help with 
>their current discussion, then I have to wonder=
 whether they 
>care about 
>communicating at all.

We actually are working=
 on the shared vocabiulary at this time, which is why I asked. I would pref=
er that we use accepted terminology, but I need some definitive source to s=
how people, so that they will accept it. Otherwise, we'll be using the term=
inology that the process police give us. :-(

Remember: large companies don=
't do anything until they've defined what they're gonna call everything.

Y=
ou know you're up against an interesting challenge, when one of the questio=
ns from an attendee is "What's a unit?"

Simon
